attributes.text:
In April 2022, Microsoft released patches for 119 vulnerabilities on its recurring Patch Tuesday disclosure. Similar to 2021, April sees the first time in the year that over 100 have been released; fortunately, while 2 of the vulnerabilities have been publicly disclosed prior to today, Microsoft has seen only 1 of the full 119 (CVE-2022-24521) exploited in the wild. This is good news for defenders in the face of other major vulnerability disclosures such as Spring4Shell in the last month. Of the 119 disclosed vulnerabilities, 10 are rated Critical by Microsoft, and aside from the exploited vulnerability, none are listed by Microsoft as receiving likely exploitation. Of the 10 critical vulnerabilities, 4 are of particular note, and all 10 are listed separately below.

CVE-2022-24521 is a vulnerability in the Windows Common Log File System Driver that was reported by the National Security Agency. It allows for privilege escalation and may be paired with another bug. Microsoft reports that this vulnerability has been exploited in the wild, although it has not released further details about threat actors, victims, or methods associated with exploitation. As a result, this vulnerability should be the priority for patching. The vulnerability has a CVSS score of 7.8.

CVE-2022-26904 is a known zero-day vulnerability in the Windows User Profile Service. Microsoft reports that there is a proof-of-concept exploit with a Metasploit module. It has a CVSS score of 7.0 and is considered to have a high level of complexity for exploitation due to conditions beyond the attackerâ€™s control. While there are no reports yet of in-the-wild exploits, the availability of a proof-of-concept exploit opens the landscape up to a larger field of opportunistic cyber threat actors.

Both CVE 2022-26809 and CVE 2022-24491 are Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerabilities affecting the Remote Procedure Call (RPC) Runtime and the Windows Network File System and have CVSS scores of 9.8. Microsoft rated them both as critical vulnerabilities, which is expected given their RCE functionality. Defenders should patch and pay attention to both vulnerabilities since exploitation of this type of vulnerability already has precedent: an earlier Windows RPC vulnerability, CVE-2017-8461, was widely exploited and also received a Metasploit module. That said, we have not yet seen reports or indicators of exploitation of either vulnerability, nor even proof-of-concept exploits along the lines of CVE-2022-26904.

The complete 10 critical vulnerabilities are:
CVE 2022-26809
CVE 2022-24547
CVE 2022-24546
CVE 2022-24542
CVE 2022-24491
CVE 2022-24481
CVE 2022-26914
CVE-2022-26904
CVE-2022-24474
CVE-2022-24497

topic.name: Regular Vendor Vulnerability Disclosures
topic.description: Vendor-specific disclosures of vulnerabilities which occur on a regular cadence, such as the MSFT and Adobe Patch Tuesday events

context_entities.name: CVE-2022-24765
context_entities.description: Git for Windows is a fork of Git containing Windows-specific patches. This vulnerability affects users working on multi-user machines, where untrusted parties have write access to the same hard disk. Those untrusted parties could create the folder `C:\.git`, which would be picked up by Git operations run supposedly outside a repository while searching for a Git directory. Git would then respect any config in said Git directory. Git Bash users who set `GIT_PS1_SHOWDIRTYSTATE` are vulnerable as well. Users who installed posh-gitare vulnerable simply by starting a PowerShell. Users of IDEs such as Visual Studio are vulnerable: simply creating a new project would already read and respect the config specified in `C:\.git\config`. Users of the Microsoft fork of Git are vulnerable simply by starting a Git Bash. The problem has been patched in Git for Windows v2.35.2. Users unable to upgrade may create the folder `.git` on all drives where Git commands are run, and remove read/write access fro

context_entities.description: Windows RPC with Routing and Remote Access enabled in Windows XP and Windows Server 2003 allows an attacker to execute code on a targeted RPC server which has Routing and Remote Access enabled via a specially crafted application, aka "Windows RPC Remote Code Execution Vulnerability."
